What: Rise of nationalism in countries, often exclusionary, notion of nation state
Why: Evolution of political nationalism, helped lead to ww1 due to lack of comprimise
Details: Increasingly exclusionary (Ignorance of others that aren’t the same), but excellent at mobilizing citizens. Introduced notion of “nation state”, previously thought of where you came from.

Who: French, British, Germany, Others (Italy, Russia, Japan, US, Austro-Hungary)
What: “extension of political or economic control (direct/indirect) by one state over another (mostly in a far away region), possessing a different culture or race, supported by a body of ideas, justifying the process”
Where: Globe - Large colonies in Africa, Asia
Why: Led to large control of resources in Europe, Strengthened conservative elements domestically, Sharpened international competition, Raised living standards, But also growing anti-imperial criticism
Details:
British - All-encompassing, based on naval power, “White Man’s burden”
France - Mediterranean proximity, “Mission civilisatrice”, Near war with Britain at Fashoda, 1898
Germany - Latecomer, Grabbing what was left, Upsetting established division

What: Rise of personal enrichment, economic organization and raw materials and production
Why: Rise of individualism, better economic output. Tied to capitalism.

What: Notion of rights, liberty and equality for all citizens. Also rise of democracy, rule of law. Rejecting hereditary privilege, free markets.
Why: Tied to rise of democracy and liberalism.
Source:
Lecture 2: Lessons of Imperialism. 1/9
Lecture 3: European Society in 1900 and the Age of Total War. 1/11

What: International system organized around five great powers, Non-system system  conferences and congresses, adjustment through war
Why: Change to existing land distributions required war. If one great nation was attacked, it significantly increased the likelihood of others attacking

Who: Conservatives in European countries moving forward with liberal ideas
What: Favors tradition in face of forces for change. Status quo, value of a previous time.
Why: Backlash to force for change
Source: Lecture 3: European Society in 1900 and the Age of Total War. 1/11

What: Analyzed class relations, critical of capitalism. Notion of class struggle and that working class should establish socialism — shared ownership of the means of production
Source: Lecture 3: European Society in 1900 and the Age of Total War. 1/11

What: Germany and Austria with Italy later in 1882
Details: All independent agreements, no coherent system

What: Franco-Russian in 1894, Franco-English in 1904, all in 1907
Details: All independent agreements, no coherent system. Fashoda Crisis, 1904 confirmed Entente Cordiale

What: Notion that Russia should support all slavs, particularly in the Balkans
When: Russian support after 1903 due to Serbian coup
Details: Serbia independent since 1878, but not allowed to unite with Bosnia, which the Austrians took control of

Who: Russia, Turkey, Ottoman Empire, Romania, Serbia, Montenegro, Bulgaria
What: Ended Russo-Turkish War, De jure recognition of de facto independent Romania, Serbia and Montenegro, Autonomous Bulgaria, increased Austrian influence in area.

1st - Germany, annoyed at Fr annexation demanded open door for commercial interests and pushed for Moroccan independence. Helped dev English and French relationship
2nd - Germans backed sultan after Fr occupied Fez and Rabat
Why: Helped dev English and French relationship

What: Attack France through neutral Belgium, strike before Russia can fully mobilize. Take out Fr in a month
Why: Germany didn’t want to fight on two fronts. Caused Br to join due to the “Rape of Belgium”
Details: Miscalculated, faster Russian mobilization than expected. Were not able to defeat French on anticipated timeline.

What: Groups of young men from the same town signing up together, eventually forming a batallion
Why: Devastating due to the fact that if a battalion was killed, an entire town was devastated.
Details: Later would be stopped.
Source:
Lecture 5:Winding Road to World War. 1/26
Lecture 7: World War I and the Home 
Front . 1/22

What: Germany pushed French as far back as the Marne River (outskirts of Paris). French manage to hold back German advances. Settles into 4 years of trench warfare.
Why: Shows preparedness of both Germany and France
Details: Taxis took troops to the front line!

Id: Battle of Tannersberg and Masurian Lakes
What: Russia attacks Germany at Battle of Tannersberg and Masurian Lakes. German Success.
Austrians defeated by Russians; large casualties. Terrorized Jewish population.
Why: Russia gained 100 miles into 	Carpathian Mountains, began siege on Przemyśl; Austrians surrendered after 133 days. Germany has to bail out Austria.

What: Center of network of French fortresses. French held the line “They shall not pass!”
Details: Stalemate in the trenches at this point. War of attrition.

What: War of Attrition. Victory no longer achievable by decisive victory, must bleed the French white.
Details: Battle of Verdun was Trench warfare

Who: Entente (mostly British) and Central Powers (mostly Germany)
What: Prize rules no longer practical for winning decisive advantage. Germany intermittently used it. Officially introduced in 1917
Why: Led to US entry in war after sinking of the Lusitania (April 6th, 1917).

What: Blockaded supplies from entering Central Powers.
Why: 500,000-750,000 died in Central Europe. Helpful in war for Entente

What: Germany proposed Mexico align with Germany and invade America.
Why: Made Americans furious

What: Political Truce in France that united the leftist with the French government. Meant that there were no strikes for the first couple years (until 1917 due to inflation vastly outpacing wages).
Details: Spirit of 1914, everyone though the war was going to be over quickly
Source: Lecture 7: World War I and the Home Front. 1/22

What: All males between 16-65 required to do some sort of national service, called Auxiliary Service Law. Intended to double industrial output. Had to work in a factory or on a farm.
Details: War government consolidated under military authority
Source: Lecture 7: World War I and the Home Front. 1/22

What: Food and other commodities government regulated, Increasingly expensive or impossible to get, Inflation
Details: Germany had “Turnip Winter”. Crops failed, had major shortages. Low morale.
Source: Lecture 7: World War I and the Home Front. 1/22

What: Massive unrest in Russia (Tsar abdicated, Bolshevik Revolution). Sued for a separate peace with Central Powers.
Why: Helped free up Germany supplies to fight in the west/France. By that time though, supplies were small, had to do Ludendorff Offensive (failed).
Source: Lecture 8: Discussion of World War I. 1/25

Who: US, France, Britain, Russia and Germany
What: Germans believed that the Treat of Versailles was dictated to them “diktat”, had no part in negotiations.
Details: War Guilt clause angered germans as well.

What: Traditional War Aims, made it super terrible for the Germans. Contained the “War Guilt” clause, which stated that Germany was wholly responsible for the war. Germany obviously not happy. Germany loses 1/7th of territory. Loses 1/10th of population. Germany army was limited to 100,000 men. Huge power imbalance.
Details: War Guilt clause angered germans as well.

What: Notion of how to create a new world order. Create counter with self-determination. Wanted League of Nations.
Why: Attempt to form world order

What: Germany somewhat agrees. Conflicts with Fr and Br goals.
Why: Attempt as world peace and world order. Failed, but very influential on today’s UN.

What: Creation of Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, Poland, Romania nations. 30 million people into nation- states of which they weren’t members.
Why: After negotiations and establish in treaty of versailles

What: Lvov and then Kerensky as prime minister. After Feb Revolution.
Source:
Lecture 10: Background to the Russian 
Revolution. 1/30

What: Worker Unions/Councils. Work together with provisional government until Lenin. Remerge in 1917. Large following from army.
Source:
Lecture 10: Background to the Russian 
Revolution. 1/30

What: Led by Lenin. Full blown socialists and communists.
Why: Reemerge on April 17th, 1917 when Lenin announces April Theses. “All Power to Soviets”
Source:
Lecture 10: Background to the Russian 
Revolution. 1/30

What: Leader of bolsheviks. Led October Russian Revolution. Dies
Why: Need for revolution before Kerensky surrendered Petrograd to the Germans. Impatient->encourages Bolshevik leaders to prepare for revolution. Returns to Petrograd, October 7. Gets bolshevik council to place armed uprising on agenda. Kerensky then moves against the bolsheviks, which get backed by the soldiers of capital (SRs).
Source:
Lecture 10: Background to the Russian 
Revolution. 1/30

What: Prime minister of provisional government. In opposition to bolsheviks.
Source:
Lecture 10: Background to the Russian 
Revolution. 1/30

What: Military leader. Supreme leader of army. Hostile to revolution. Made inflammatory speeches. Ran into problems with Kornilov affair, where he attempted to establish a military dictatorship in Petrograd (in order to restore order). Kerensky backed out at the 11th hour. Caused soviets to rally to provisional government. Increased fears about counterrevolution.
Source:
Lecture 10: Background to the Russian 
Revolution. 1/30

What: Economic system in which commercial economic activity is undertaken by the state. Preserved what it could of existing economy, held back from nationalizing industries. Had problems with “bourgeois specialists” -> no on had expertise on how to run economy.
Goal to keep towns and Red Army stocked with food and weapons during the war. Nationalize all economies. Rationing of food, Private enterprise banned. State left foreign trade
Details: Workers forbidden to strike. Obligatory labor duty for non- working classes. -> Largely ineffective. Breakdown of society and economy on most basic levels. Led to bartering system.

What: Used terror to eliminate real and perceived enemies.
Why: Need to keep Bolsheviks in power.

What: Didn’t want Bolsheviks in power— Conservatives, liberals, tsarists, democrats. Leads to civil war. Largely uncoordinated and independent.
Details: Had international support.

What: Three Phases: Revolution to Armistice (October 1917 – November 1918), White Army advances; Red Army counterattacks (January – November 1919) and White siege of Crimea; evacuated to Constantinople, November 1920, Bolsheviks regaining control in the east (1920 – 1922).
Details: White forces coalescing in summer 1918, Cossack General Kaledin taking control in the Don region; gathering a Volunteer Army. 	Fighting largely sporadic. Red Army only had relatively small stronghold of major cities. Japan eventually attacks in Asia/Vladivostok. After Red counterattacks in late 1919, war steadily wound down.

What: Sided with Lenin for socialist revolution. Voted for Brest-Litovsk. Stalin became Secretary General of Bolshevik Party (now called the Communist Party), 1922. Starts to eliminate rivals.
Details: Less cosmopolitan and theoretical than other well-known Bolsheviks. Increasing cult of personality, embarks on violent project of modernizing the Soviet Union through collectivization and industrialization.

Who: Russian, Transcaucasian, Ukrainian, and Belorussian republics
What: United Soviet Socialist Republics
Theory put forth by Stalin, soviet union should start to strengthen itself through national communism.
Increased amount of egalitarianism. Social distinction, gender relationships changing. Mass-produced clothing. Women working outside of the home. Changed gender relationships. Emancipation of youth.
Details: Backlash from religious leaders, traditionalists, and right wing movements

What: Rise of popular culture. Newspapers, radio, film. Development of Mass Leisure

Combination of two of the greatest ideologies of the twentieth century: nationalism and socialism. Leadership principle, corporative hierarchy order, myth of uniqueness and superiority. Action oriented.
Details: -Anti Party, Anticapitalist, antidemocratic, totalitarianism. Industries should be organized into syndicates or confederations and industries owned and managed by the workers.
Source:
Lecture 15: Rise of Fascism in Italy 
. 2/11

What: Many in Italy felt like they didn’t get enough out of WW1, not compensated enough for loses. “unredeemed territory”
Source:
Lecture 15: Rise of Fascism in Italy 
. 2/11

What: Mussolini marching to Rome: “Either they will give us the government or we shall seize it by descending upon Rome”. Huge bluff that worked out. King frightened into accepting Mussolini as prime minister.
Source:
Lecture 15: Rise of Fascism in Italy 
. 2/11

What: 1⁄4 of popular vote gets 2/3 of seats in Chamber of Deputies. Makes Mussolini powerful and won.
Source:
Lecture 15: Rise of Fascism in Italy 
. 2/11

What: Alternative to exploitation and class war. Implementing syndicalist ideas to economy -> dividing economic activity into different corporations with management and labor making compromises.
Source:
Lecture 15: Rise of Fascism in Italy 
. 2/11

What: Friendship treaty with Germany, because increasingly ostracized by West, 1936
Details: Creating a “Berlin-Rome Axis”, 	Supported Hitler’s annexation of Austria in 1938, Pact of Steel, 1939 (military treaty).
Source:
Lecture 15: Rise of Fascism in Italy 
. 2/11

What: Deficit spending during the war, trade union pressure for higher wages, reparations = rise of wholesale prices.
Details: When Depression hits its peak in 1931 (or so), hyperinflation 10 years in the past but memory of it still strong. Dawes plan enacted in response.

What: Turn to self sufficiency. Hurts global trade as expected. Backfires.Only in 1930 did trade exceed pre-war levels.
Idea of ending gold standard and allowing for deficit spending.
Reintroduction of gold standard after WW1, for stability reasons. 1930s
Why: Britain reintroduced Gold Standard, 1925

What: Had backed off of command economy in 1920s, reintroduced some markets and capitalist mechanisms. Scissors Crisis, starting 1923. Collective farm rented to farmers, required to deliver fixed quota of grain at harvest time, Industrialization of agriculture.
Why: Kulak: 	“wealthy” peasants accusing of hoarding grain rather than selling it
Details: By 1927, peasants hoarding grain rather than sell it. 30% decline of provisions though previous harvest bountiful

What: Massive industrial projects to overtake the West. Compulsory labor.
Why: 2.5 to 10 million tons of pig iron in 2 years. Part of Industrialization effort in Russia

What: International Crisis. US ended up recalling loans to Germany. Collapse of debt service. Strongest in most industrialized countries. 1932 as worst year, failure of deflationary measures.
Details: 1929’s stock market crash. Created new pressures and political radicalization that liberal democracies struggled to effectively resist. 15 million unemployed in US, 6 million in Germany. Another 1⁄4 of workforce underemployed. Bourgeois fear of “proletarianization”: fearing downward social mobility; loss of class and status.

What: Risked demotion under Republican reforms. Assumed leadership of Spanish African Army on July 18, 1936 (30,000 soldiers). Seized control of Spanish Moroccan Protectorate.

Fascist movement on the nationalist side, founded 1933. Founded and led by Jose Antonio Primo de Rivera (later executed by Republic and succeeded by Franco). Repudiated the republican constitution, funded by Mussolini.
Details: Blamed unholy trinity of “Jews, Freemasons, and Bolsheviks” for Spain’s troubles.

What: Committed to form of progress, won 1936 election.
Details: Supported by Mexico and Soviet Union.

What: Any reform too much for Republic’s greatest opponents, the Church and the army. Falange
Details: Supported by Mussolini and Hitler. Mussolini sends 100,000 men, Hitler supplies airplanes. Luftwaffe testing its methods that would be used in WW2.

What: Painting of devastation that the Germans enacted in Guernica.
Fighters from the around the world, fighting against facism.
